p: The reducing power assay was commonly reported as a simple and robust method for measuring antioxidant power. This test is based on the conversion of Fe 3+ to Fe 2+ under the effect of essential oils. In agreement with DPPH and (H 2O 2) scavenging assays, reducing power method showed that essential oils exhibited good antioxidant activity. Thereby, the reducing powers of the tested samples increased when their concentrations were increased (Fig. 4c). As shown in Table 3, the tested oil had slightly lower antioxidant potential than BHT (EC 50 = 0.384 ± 0.102 mg/mL for BHT and EC 50 = 0.982 ± 0.24 mg/mL for tested oil), but better than methanolic extract.
